title: Can three atoms share electrons like two atoms do? - Quora

response.answer_text: Actually, electrons can be shared by lot more than two or three atoms. Those are called delocalized electrons. In Benzene ring, all six carbons share 6 pi electrons. Delocalization adds to the stability of a molecule, which is why benzene is more stable than equivalent alkene or cyclo hydrocarbon. Delocalized electron - Wikipedia Typically, you will find delocalization happening over a flat molecule with alternate C - C single and double bonds.

Yes it is possible….but if and only if it has a small size and it has the ability to form pπ-pπ bonds. Example nitrogen.
